Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} + i\\omega u = 0 \\), where \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit and \\( \\omega \\) is a constant frequency. We investigate the effects of an integral transform, specifically the Fourier Transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\), defined by \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, t) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-i\\omega x} u(x,t) \\, dx \\).

If the initial function \\( u(x,0) \\) is transformed by \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) at t = 0 and subsequently evolves according to the given partial differential equation, will the Fourier transform at time t = T, \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, T) \\), be equivalent to directly applying \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) to \\( u(x,T) \\)?
Explanation: Since the Fourier Transform of \\( u(x,t) \\) evolving under the given PDE is \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, t) = e^{-\\omega t} \\hat{u}(\\omega, 0) \\), the transformation commutes with the time evolution under this PDE. This ensures that applying the Fourier Transform to the evolved state at any time t = T yields the same result as evolving the transformed initial state.
